responses: Here’s the official UCU Mukono Campus Map: https://ucu.ac.ug/ucu-buildings/ptucker/
From the main gate: Bishop Tucker Building (with the Chapel) is the first big building you see.
Ham Mukasa Library is right in the centre of campus — walk straight past Bishop Tucker.
Nkoyoyo Hall (ladies’ hostel) is just downhill from the dining hall.
Nsibambi & Sabiiti Halls (men’s hostels) are behind the dining hall area.
Janan Luwum Dining Hall is the big cafeteria — you’ll smell the food!
M-Block (Maari) & K-Block (Kivengere) are the two main lecture blocks side by side.
N-Block (Noll) is the tall computer lab and lecture building next to them.
Allan Galpin Health Centre is between the hostels and lecture blocks — short walk from dining hall.
Sports Complex & Gym are behind Technology Park — follow the road past the hostels.
Guild Building is near the dining hall and sports ground.
Finance Office is in the orange Administration Block below Nkoyoyo Hall.
Dean of Students & Registrar are in Bishop Tucker Building.
Technology Park (computing & engineering) is near the back gate and sports area.
Need step-by-step directions from one place to another? Just tell me start and end point — I’ll guide you!

responses: Allan Galpin Health Centre sits between the student residential halls and the main lecture blocks, a short walk downhill from Janan Luwum Dining Hall.
From the main gate, walk past Bishop Tucker Building toward Nkoyoyo Hall; the Allan Galpin clinic is on the left opposite the student hostels before you reach N-Block.
Follow the signs for student health services — the Allan Galpin outpatient wing is behind the dining hall beside the student affairs offices.

responses: Bishop Tucker Building is the first major block after the main gate; it anchors the chapel on one side and houses the Vice Chancellor's office plus key administrative units.
Walk straight from the main entrance into the central courtyard—the stone Bishop Tucker Building sits opposite the chapel and hosts the VC, Dean of Students, and registries.
Think of Bishop Tucker as campus headquarters: the chapel is at its heart, with guild, deanery, and senior management offices in the surrounding wings.

responses: Ham Mukasa Library has 3 beautiful floors full of resources — welcome!
Yes! Undergraduates can borrow up to 6 books for 14 days. Renew online via Koha.
Use your student number + default password (date of birth: ddmmyyyy) to log into Koha: https://koha.ucu.ac.ug
Renew books online up to 2 times if no one has reserved them. Easy!
Late fine: UGX 500 per day per book — check your Koha account to avoid surprises!
Discussion/seminar rooms: Book at the circulation desk or online (first-come, first-served).
Free printing & scanning available in the ICT corner — bring your student ID.
Strong eduroam Wi-Fi everywhere + 70+ computers for your use.
Past exam papers → Uganda Collection, Ground Floor. Ask the librarian!
JSTOR, EBSCO, Emerald, etc. → Access via library website with your UCU login.
UCU Institutional Repository: https://repository.ucu.ac.ug — theses, journals, past papers.
Silent reading rooms on 2nd floor — perfect for deep focus and prayerful study.
Group study zones available — book early during exam season!
Theological books section is on the 1st floor — one of the best in East Africa!
Need a book we don’t have? Fill the acquisition request form at the desk — we love suggestions!
Reference librarians are always ready to help — just ask at any counter!
Library orientation happens every semester — highly recommended for freshers!
Water is allowed (in transparent bottles). Food is not — let’s keep the books safe!
Drop box at the entrance — return books even when library is closed.
Alumni can access e-resources and reading rooms with an alumni card.
Laptops/tablets not loaned, but plenty of power sockets and desktop computers.
Final-year students get priority for postgraduate reading room on 3rd floor.
Yes — we run free workshops on Koha, research skills, Zotero, and more!
Remote access to all databases — just log in with your UCU email from anywhere.
Your student ID card is your library card — keep it safe!
Reading terrace on the top floor — quiet, breezy, and inspiring!
Need help with your thesis? Our librarians offer one-on-one research consultations.
Overnight study allowed during revision week — check library notices!
Yes — group tutoring allowed in booked seminar rooms (max 10 people).
You can donate books! Bring them to the circulation desk — we’ll be grateful!

responses: Regular semester schedule: Mon–Thu 08:00–22:00, Fri 08:00–20:00, Sat 09:00–17:00; the library is closed on Sundays except during revision weeks.
During exams, Ham Mukasa Library usually extends hours up to midnight—watch the library noticeboard or Koha banner for any special updates.
Public holidays follow the university closure calendar, so confirm on the library WhatsApp alert before heading over.

responses: UCU offers over 70 programmes across 7 faculties: Business, IT & Engineering, Law, Medicine, Theology, Social Sciences, Education, and Public Health.
Yes! We have Bachelor of Science in Computer Science (BSc CS) and Bachelor of Science in Data Science & Analytics.
BBA (Bachelor of Business Administration) takes 3 years full-time. Evening/weekend option also available.
Entry for BBA: Minimum two principal passes (e.g. Economics, Maths, Entrepreneurship) + credit in Maths at O-Level.
Yes — we offer Master of Information Technology (MIT), MBA, Master of Public Health, and many more postgraduate degrees.
Engineering: BSc Civil & Environmental Engineering and BSc Electronics & Communication Engineering.
School of Medicine offers Bachelor of Medicine & Bachelor of Surgery (MBChB) — 5 years + 1 year internship.
Bishop Tucker School of Divinity & Theology offers Bachelor of Divinity, MA Theology, and PhD in Theology.
Yes — we have a strong Bachelor of Laws (LLB), Bachelor of Journalism & Communication, and Bachelor of Social Work & Social Administration.
All undergraduate degrees are 3 years except Medicine (5+1), Nursing (4), and Pharmacy (4).
Most programmes include a mandatory internship/recitation in Year 2 or 3 — especially IT, Business, Engineering, and Health Sciences.
Yes — we offer evening and weekend classes in Business, Education, and some IT programmes.
We run professional short courses: Project Management, First Aid, Health Informatics, Digital Marketing, Procurement, etc.
PhD programmes available in Theology, Education, Business, and more coming soon.
Yes — Civil & Environmental Engineering is offered (4 years).
BSc Data Science & Analytics is one of our newest and most popular programmes!
Postgraduate diplomas: Human Resource Management, Public Health, Christian Ministries, Sustainable Business, etc.
Course catalogue & detailed syllabi: https://ucu.ac.ug/academics/programmes/
Moodle has all lecture notes, slides, and recommended textbooks once you’re registered.
Grading: A (80–100), B+ (75–79), B (70–74) … down to F (<40). GPA 4.40–5.00 = First Class.
Most final-year students do a research project or thesis — especially in Sciences, Business, IT, and Social Sciences.
Entrepreneurship, Ethics, and Christian Worldview are popular electives across faculties.
You can withdraw/add courses within the first 3 weeks of semester via Alpha portal.
Assessment: Coursework 40%, Final exam 60% (typical). Some courses have 100% coursework.
Yes — Mass Communication & Journalism is offered under the Faculty of Journalism, Media & Communication.
Need the exact timetable? Log into Alpha → Registration → Timetable for next semester.
Lab courses: Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Computer Labs, Engineering Workshops, Nursing Skills Lab.
Distance/blended learning (ODeL) available in some postgraduate and short courses.
Accounting & Finance (BSAF) covers Financial Accounting, Auditing, Taxation, Management Accounting, and more.
Theological library section is excellent — perfect for Divinity students!
Want to know more about a specific programme? Just mention the name — I’ll give you full details!
New in 2025: Bachelor of Software Engineering and Bachelor of Nursing Science (Direct Entry).
Scholarships available for Medicine, Engineering, and high-performing students — apply early!
All programmes include compulsory Christian Ethics and Development Studies courses — that’s the UCU difference!
Still undecided? Come for career guidance at the Student Centre — we’d love to help you choose!
God has a great plan for your studies here at UCU — which programme is He calling you to?

responses: UCU Technology Week is organized by University ICT Services (UIS) to promote digital literacy and innovation.
You can join UCU Tech Week workshops for free — check UIS announcements on the student portal.
During UCU Tech Week, there are cyber-security sessions, cloud computing classes, and Alpha MIS tutorials.
The laptop clinic during Tech Week helps students check and optimize their devices.
Alpha MIS training is part of Tech Week so that you can learn registration, results, and portal features.
There are practical labs, hackathons, and networking booths during UCU Technology Week.
UIS brings in alumni and tech companies to speak and mentor students during the week.
Many students receive certificates at the end of Tech Week for attending workshops.
If you volunteer, you may help run sessions, mentor, or assist with registrations.
Tech Week is held on the Mukono campus, often around the library courtyard and Technology Park.
You can learn about eduroam, OneDrive, Teams, and other digital tools during Tech Week.
A data-science bootcamp is sometimes offered during UCU Tech Week.
UIS offers cloud computing sessions, AI explorations, and startup mentorship during Tech Week.
There are resume clinics and interview prep sessions as part of UCU Tech Week events.
Hackathons and student project displays take place during UCU Technology Week.
Remote students can join some Tech Week activities via online links shared by UIS.
You don't have to pay for UCU Tech Week — many sessions are free for students.
UIS shares the Tech Week schedule on the student portal and via email before the event.
Community startups and student teams often showcase their work during Tech Week.
Tech Week is a great chance to meet tech alumni, local entrepreneurs, and UIS staff.
There's a design thinking workshop, innovation labs, and entrepreneurship sessions during UCU Tech Week.
Students interested in app development get to present their ideas and get mentorship.
Tech Week includes interactive Q&A sessions with UIS leadership.
Cybersecurity certification classes run during UCU Tech Week for interested students.
There are cloud-security and safe internet-use seminars in Tech Week.
At the end of UCU Technology Week, there is a demo day for student projects.
Tech Week occurs once every major semester — keep an eye on UIS announcements.
First-year students can benefit greatly from the basic Alpha and portal sessions.
Alumni mentors often lead sessions on entrepreneurship during UCU Tech Week.
There are IoT and robotics showcases sometimes during UCU Tech Week.
Workshops on cloud infrastructure, networking, and software dev are common in Tech Week.
Many students attend Tech Week to improve their digital literacy and build their resumes.
You can register for specific Tech Week sessions via a form shared by UIS.
UIS provides support throughout the week — including device diagnostics, software help.
Digital security and phishing awareness are emphasized during UCU Tech Week.
Design thinking and startup creation are encouraged via innovation labs during Tech Week.
There are mentorship opportunities for students to pitch ideas to entrepreneurs.
You can get certificate of participation for Tech Week workshops at UCU.
Tech Week is open to all UCU students — not just those in computer science.
UIS coordinates with faculties so that some events are faculty-specific during the week.
